The government filed an opposition on April 4, 2025, arguing that Erie County had not demonstrated imminent irreparable harm, that the court lacked jurisdiction because this was essentially a contract dispute, that the claims were not ripe since no final adverse action had been taken, and that Erie County was unlikely to succeed on the merits.

The case was voluntarily dismissed without prejudice on April 14, 2025, when Erie County filed a notice stating that "Defendant has changed its certification requirements since the filing of this suit." The preliminary injunction motion was withdrawn as moot. The case's connection to a related nationwide challenge to the executive orders in National Association of Diversity Officers in Higher Education v. Trump in the District of Maryland, which was preliminarily enjoined and then stayed by the Fourth Circuit, likely influenced the procedural developments that led to the voluntary dismissal.
results.46353:
On April 7, 2025, a software engineer proceeding under the pseudonym John Doe filed suit in the Northern District of California against President Donald J. Trump, DHS Secretary Kristi Noem, ICE Acting Director Todd M. Lyons, and ICE San Francisco Acting Field Office Director Moises Becerra. The plaintiff, represented by private counsel from Van Der Hout LLP, challenged the unlawful termination of his record in the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS). Judge Jeffrey S. White was assigned to the case.

The case arose from the government's abrupt termination of plaintiff's SEVIS record on March 28, 2025. Plaintiff, a national of a predominantly Muslim country, was working in California pursuant to post-graduate Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Optional Practical Training (OPT) employment authorization under his F-1 student status. ICE terminated his SEVIS record, marking him as "Otherwise Failing to Maintain Status" and citing that he had been "identified in criminal records check," referencing Immigration and Nationality Act section 237(a)(1)(C)(i) for failure to maintain status.

Plaintiff's only criminal history consisted of a minor misdemeanor conviction for which he received probation. This conviction was not for a crime of violence, did not carry a potential sentence of more than one year, and did not render him inadmissible or deportable. Importantly, DHS had known about this conviction for months and had twice approved immigration benefits applications for plaintiff after learning of it.

The SEVIS termination was part of what appeared to be a broader policy targeting hundreds, if not more, F-1 students nationwide, particularly those from African, Arab, Middle Eastern, Muslim, and Asian backgrounds. Many affected students had their F-1 visas revoked by the State Department and received communications suggesting they should "self-deport" using the CBP Home app. Some students were arrested and transferred to detention facilities in Louisiana and Texas, often far from their homes and communities.

Plaintiff brought claims under the Administrative Procedure Act alleging the SEVIS termination was arbitrary, capricious, and exceeded statutory authority, as well as Fifth Amendment due process claims for lack of notice and opportunity to respond. He sought declaratory judgment that the termination was unlawful, restoration of his SEVIS record, and injunctive relief preventing enforcement action against him.

On April 16, 2025, plaintiff filed a motion for temporary restraining order. Judge White granted the TRO on April 17, 2025, and extended it on April 25, 2025, after a hearing where the government indicated it was beginning to reactivate SEVIS records. The court consolidated approximately eight or nine related cases involving similar challenges by other international students.

Following the initial hearing, the government filed a statement on April 25, 2025, indicating that ICE was developing a new policy framework for SEVIS record terminations and that affected students' records would remain active or be reactivated until the new policy was implemented. The government stated it retained authority to terminate SEVIS records for other lawful reasons but would not act under the challenged policy.

On May 22, 2025, Judge White granted motions for preliminary injunction in the consolidated cases. The government appealed to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals on July 21, 2025 (Case No. 25-4514), and filed a motion to stay pending appeal. On August 22, 2025, Judge White granted the motion to stay in part and denied it in part, allowing some aspects of the preliminary injunction to remain in effect during the appeal.

The case highlighted tensions between immigration enforcement and due process rights for international students, particularly regarding the relationship between SEVIS database entries and actual F-1 immigration status, and whether administrative actions affecting student status require notice and opportunity to respond before implementation.

On March 17, 2025, Master Sergeant Logan Ireland and Staff Sergeant Nicholas Bear Bade, two transgender men serving in the United States Air Force, filed suit in the District of New Jersey challenging President Trump's ban on transgender military service. The plaintiffs were represented by GLBTQ Legal Advocates & Defenders, the National Center for Lesbian Rights, and private counsel.

The case challenged two Executive Orders: Executive Order 14183 ("Prioritizing Military Excellence and Readiness") issued January 27, 2025, which banned transgender individuals from military service, and Executive Order 14168 ("Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism") issued January 20, 2025, which defined sex as "immutable biological classification" and required all federal policies to use this definition. The orders were implemented through subsequent Department of Defense and Air Force memoranda issued between January and March 2025.

Both plaintiffs had exemplary military records. Master Sergeant Ireland served over fourteen years with multiple overseas deployments to Afghanistan, Qatar, South Korea, and the United Arab Emirates, earning four Air Force Commendation Medals and other honors. Staff Sergeant Bade served six years including deployment to Kuwait, receiving various awards including the Military Outstanding Volunteer Service Medal. Both had medically transitioned and were serving openly as transgender men when the policy changed.

The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Fifth Amendment's Equal Protection and Due Process clauses, arguing that the ban discriminated based on sex and transgender status without adequate justification and was motivated by animus. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent enforcement of the ban against them and more broadly.

Following the policy change, both plaintiffs were immediately placed on administrative absence and removed from their assignments—Ireland from training at Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst and Bade from deployment in Kuwait. They faced imminent involuntary administrative separation proceedings that could begin as early as March 26, 2025.

On March 18, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a temporary restraining order. Judge Christine P. O'Hearn issued an Order to Show Cause, scheduling a hearing for March 24, 2025. The case proceeded alongside parallel litigation in Talbott v. United States in the D.C. District Court, which had resulted in a nationwide preliminary injunction against the same policies.

After a hearing on March 24, 2025, Judge O'Hearn granted a 14-day temporary restraining order, finding that the plaintiffs demonstrated likelihood of success on their equal protection claims, irreparable harm from forced separation and reputational damage, and that the balance of equities favored relief. The court applied intermediate scrutiny, concluding the orders classified based on sex and transgender status, and found defendants failed to provide adequate justification for the differential treatment.

The defendants, led by the Department of Justice, opposed the motion arguing for military deference and that any separation proceedings provided adequate procedural protections. They also sought a brief stay of the TRO to coordinate with parallel cases, which Judge O'Hearn denied on March 26, 2025.

The case was voluntarily dismissed without prejudice on May 15, 2025, likely due to developments in the broader litigation challenging the transgender military service ban.

On March 15, 2025, three plaintiffs filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York challenging two executive orders issued by President Trump. The plaintiffs were Momodou Taal, a non-citizen PhD student from the United Kingdom and Gambia studying at Cornell University; Mũkoma Wa Ngũgĩ, a U.S. citizen and Cornell professor; and Sriram Parasurama, a U.S. citizen and Cornell PhD student. The defendants included President Trump, the Department of Homeland Security, and Secretary Kristi Noem, with additional defendants added in an amended complaint filed March 27, 2025.

The case was assigned to Judge Elizabeth C. Coombe. The plaintiffs were represented by private counsel and attorneys from the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee and other legal organizations.

The lawsuit challenged Executive Order 14161, "Protecting the United States from Foreign Terrorists and Other National Security and Public Safety Threats," issued January 30, 2025, and Executive Order 14188, "Additional Measures to Combat Anti-Semitism," issued February 3, 2025. The plaintiffs alleged these orders violated their First Amendment rights to free speech, to receive information, and to free association, as well as Fifth Amendment due process rights.

The factual basis centered on the government's enforcement of these orders against non-citizens who engaged in pro-Palestinian advocacy or criticism of U.S. foreign policy. Mr. Taal had been an outspoken critic of U.S. support for Israel and had participated in campus protests supporting Palestinian rights. The State Department revoked his student visa on March 14, 2025, and Immigration and Customs Enforcement attempted to detain him for removal proceedings. The government acknowledged that Mr. Taal's "involvement in certain protests at Cornell University" aligned with the executive orders' focus on deporting individuals who perpetuate "unlawful anti-Semitic harassment," even though he faced no criminal charges and Cornell found no evidence of violence or antisemitic behavior.

The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, arguing the executive orders were unconstitutionally vague and overbroad, constituted viewpoint-based discrimination, and chilled protected speech. They filed multiple emergency motions for temporary restraining orders to prevent Mr. Taal's detention and deportation while the case was pending.

On March 27, 2025, Judge Coombe issued a decision and order denying the plaintiffs' motions for temporary restraining orders. The court found that plaintiffs had not established subject matter jurisdiction over Mr. Taal's claim to enjoin his removal proceedings, citing jurisdiction-stripping provisions in federal immigration law. The court also found that plaintiffs had not established standing for their claims challenging the executive orders, noting that the orders appeared to state policy intentions rather than create immediately enforceable regulatory action.

Following the court's denial of emergency relief, the plaintiffs filed a notice of voluntary dismissal without prejudice on March 31, 2025, pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 41(a)(1)(A)(i). The court entered an order closing the case on April 2, 2025.

The case involved constitutional challenges to executive immigration enforcement policies and raised significant questions about the scope of First Amendment protections for non-citizens and the limits of executive authority over immigration matters involving protected speech.

On March 12, 2025, Dr. Gordon Schiff and Dr. Celeste Royce, both physicians and Harvard Medical School professors, filed suit against the U.S. Office of Personnel Management and its Acting Director Charles Ezell, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services and its Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., and the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality and its Acting Director Mamatha S. Pancholi. The plaintiffs were represented by the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation and the Media Freedom & Information Access Clinic at Yale Law School. The case is assigned to Judge Leo T. Sorokin.

The lawsuit challenges the removal of the plaintiffs' medical research articles from PSNet (Patient Safety Network), a government-operated website that serves as the leading patient safety resource in the United States. PSNet, managed by AHRQ within HHS, hosts expert commentaries on medical errors to help healthcare providers prevent similar mistakes in the future. Dr. Schiff had authored a commentary on suicide risk assessment that listed "transgender" and "LGBTQ" individuals among high-risk groups, supported by citations to peer-reviewed medical literature. Dr. Royce had authored a commentary on endometriosis diagnosis that noted the condition "can occur in trans and non-gender-conforming people" and that failure to understand this fact could make diagnosis more challenging.

On January 20, 2025, President Trump issued Executive Order 14168, titled "Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government." The order directed federal agencies to "remove all statements, policies, regulations, forms, communications, or other internal and external messages that promote or otherwise inculcate gender ideology." On January 29, 2025, OPM's Acting Director issued a memorandum instructing agencies to "take down all outward facing media (websites, social media accounts, etc.) that inculcate or promote gender ideology" by January 31, 2025. HHS issued implementing guidance on January 31, 2025.

In response to these directives, AHRQ conducted word searches through PSNet's database and identified approximately 20 articles containing terminology potentially conflicting with the Executive Order, including the plaintiffs' commentaries. AHRQ removed these articles and offered to repost them only if the authors agreed to delete "problematic words" such as "transgender" and "LGBTQ." Both plaintiffs refused, believing such changes would compromise the scientific accuracy and patient safety value of their work.

The plaintiffs allege violations of the First Amendment based on viewpoint discrimination in a limited public forum and violations of the Administrative Procedure Act on grounds that the agency actions were arbitrary and capricious and that OPM exceeded its statutory authority. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief to restore their articles to PSNet and prevent future censorship.

On April 1, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary injunction. The defendants opposed the motion, arguing among other things that PSNet's technical support contract had expired on March 24, 2025, making the website static and unable to accept new content. After a hearing on May 21, 2025, Judge Sorokin granted the motion in part on May 23, 2025. The court found the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their First Amendment claim because the defendants' actions constituted viewpoint discrimination, which is prohibited even in limited public forums. The court ordered the defendants to restore the plaintiffs' commentaries and all other content authored by private parties that was removed from PSNet pursuant to the Executive Order implementation within seven days.

On June 16, 2025, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the complaint for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, arguing the claims are moot, the plaintiffs lack standing, and challenges to future implementation of the OPM memorandum are not ripe. The case mentions a related lawsuit, Doctors for America et al. v. OPM et al., pending in the D.C. District Court addressing similar implementation issues with the Executive Order.

Learning Resources, Inc. and hand2mind, Inc., two family-owned educational toy companies based in Illinois, filed this lawsuit on April 22, 2025, against President Donald Trump and various federal officials and agencies, represented by private counsel from Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld LLP. The companies challenged President Trump's invocation of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to impose sweeping tariffs on imports, claiming the statute does not authorize tariffs and that such authority belongs exclusively to Congress under Article I of the Constitution.

The legal challenge arose from a series of executive orders issued beginning February 1, 2025, where President Trump used IEEPA to impose tariffs ranging from 10% to 145% on goods from China and other countries. The President declared national emergencies based on the fentanyl crisis and persistent U.S. trade deficits, then imposed these tariffs by modifying the Harmonized Tariff Schedule. The plaintiffs, who import about 60% of their products from China and other affected countries, faced potential tariff costs exceeding $100 million annually—a 40-fold increase that threatened their business survival.

The defendants moved to transfer the case to the U.S. Court of International Trade, arguing that court had exclusive jurisdiction over tariff-related matters under 28 U.S.C. § 1581(i). Simultaneously, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction. Judge Rudolph Contreras heard both motions on May 27, 2025.

On May 29, 2025, Judge Contreras issued a memorandum opinion and order denying the motion to transfer and granting the preliminary injunction. The court determined it had jurisdiction because IEEPA is not a "law providing for tariffs" within the meaning of the jurisdictional statute, finding instead that IEEPA's grant of power to "regulate importation" does not encompass the authority to impose revenue-raising tariffs. The court concluded that the power to regulate and the power to tax are constitutionally distinct, that no president had previously used IEEPA to impose tariffs, and that Congress had created specific, limited statutory frameworks for presidential tariff authority that would be rendered meaningless if IEEPA provided unlimited tariffing power.

The court stayed its preliminary injunction for 14 days to allow appellate review. Defendants immediately appealed to the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals on May 29, 2025, and moved for a stay pending appeal on June 2, 2025. Judge Contreras granted the stay motion on June 3, 2025, noting that the Court of International Trade had issued a broader injunction in a related case that was subsequently stayed by the Federal Circuit, and concluding that a stay was appropriate to protect presidential authority over national security and foreign policy during the pendency of the appeal. The case is currently stayed pending resolution of the D.C. Circuit appeal.

Multiple amicus briefs were filed, including one supporting defendants' transfer motion from America First Legal Foundation, one supporting plaintiffs' preliminary injunction from prominent legal scholars and former government officials, and one from other small businesses opposing the transfer motion. The case involves claims that IEEPA does not authorize the challenged tariffs, that the agency implementation violates the Administrative Procedure Act, and that if IEEPA does authorize such broad tariff authority, it would violate the nondelegation doctrine.

Chen v. Noem was filed on April 11, 2025, in the Northern District of California before Judge Jeffrey S. White. The case challenges the Department of Homeland Security's "Student Criminal Alien Initiative," a policy implemented in early April 2025 where ICE ran nearly 1.3 million F-1 visa holders through the National Crime Information Center database and terminated the SEVIS records of thousands of international students based solely on any law enforcement contact, regardless of whether charges were filed or convictions obtained.

The plaintiffs are six Chinese nationals pursuing graduate degrees or post-graduation employment: Zhuoer Chen (UC Berkeley architecture student), Mengcheng Yu (Carnegie Mellon educational technology student), Jiarong Ouyang (University of Cincinnati statistics PhD candidate), Jing Tao (UT Dallas political science PhD student), Yifeng Wu (NYU undergraduate), and Wanrong Li (USC analytics graduate working under Optional Practical Training). None have criminal convictions, though some had minor law enforcement contact resulting in dismissed or expunged charges. The plaintiffs are represented by private counsel from Deheng Law Offices PC and the Chinese American Legal Defense Alliance.

The students challenge the mass SEVIS terminations under the Administrative Procedure Act as arbitrary and capricious agency action contrary to law, and under the Fifth Amendment's Due Process and Equal Protection clauses. They argue that ICE terminated their student status without notice, individualized review, or legal justification, violating basic due process rights and discriminating based on national origin. The complaint also challenges the Department of State's subsequent mass revocation of F-1 visas based on the same database hits, arguing State lacks authority under 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i) to revoke visas of people already present in the United States.

On April 18, 2025, Judge Susan Illston granted an ex parte temporary restraining order protecting the named plaintiffs. The case was then reassigned to Judge Jeffrey S. White and consolidated with multiple related cases involving similarly situated students. On May 22, 2025, Judge White granted a nationwide preliminary injunction after ICE had already restored the plaintiffs' SEVIS records. The injunction prohibits defendants from arresting or detaining the plaintiffs and similarly situated students, imposing adverse effects from the terminated SEVIS records, and reversing the reinstatement of SEVIS records without following proper regulatory procedures under 8 C.F.R. § 214.1.

The defendants filed a notice of appeal to the Ninth Circuit on July 21, 2025 (Case No. 25-4521), and moved to stay the nationwide scope of the preliminary injunction, arguing it exceeds the court's authority under the Supreme Court's decision in Trump v. CASA and improperly restricts law enforcement activities unrelated to the SEVIS terminations. The plaintiffs filed a first amended complaint on July 29, 2025, adding the new plaintiffs and claims against the Secretary of State, and moved for an amended preliminary injunction to address the visa revocations that remain in effect despite the restoration of SEVIS records.

On February 11, 2025, federal employee unions and current and former federal employees filed suit in the Southern District of New York against the U.S. Office of Personnel Management and other defendants for alleged violations of privacy laws. The plaintiffs are represented by counsel from the Electronic Frontier Foundation, Lex Lumina LLP, State Democracy Defenders Fund, and The Chandra Law Firm.

The case centers on events following President Trump's January 20, 2025 inauguration, when he signed Executive Order 14,158 establishing the "Department of Government Efficiency" (DOGE) and renaming the U.S. Digital Service as the United States DOGE Service. According to the complaint, OPM immediately granted broad access to its personnel systems to individuals associated with DOGE, including systems containing sensitive personal information of tens of millions of current and former federal employees such as social security numbers, health records, financial information, and family member data.

The plaintiffs brought five claims for relief under the Privacy Act of 1974 (5 U.S.C. § 552a) and the Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. § 701 et seq.), along with an ultra vires claim. They alleged that OPM disclosed records to DOGE agents who were not OPM employees or lacked the requisite need for access under Privacy Act exception (b)(1), and that OMP failed to establish appropriate safeguards to ensure security and confidentiality of records as required by the Privacy Act. The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief but not monetary damages.

On February 14, 2025, plaintiffs filed a motion for a temporary restraining order. The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on March 14, 2025. Judge Denise L. Cote largely denied the motion to dismiss in an opinion issued April 3, 2025 (2025 WL 996542), finding that the complaint adequately alleged violations of the Privacy Act and APA based on disclosure of OPM records to individuals who were not OPM employees or did not have sufficient need for access.

The plaintiffs then filed a motion for preliminary injunction on April 25, 2025. After a hearing on May 29, 2025, Judge Cote granted the preliminary injunction in an opinion issued June 9, 2025. The court found that plaintiffs had demonstrated a likelihood of success on their Privacy Act and APA claims, irreparable harm from the unauthorized disclosure of sensitive personal information, and that the public interest favored enforcement of privacy protections. The preliminary injunction was issued June 20, 2025, with an administrative stay of fourteen days and requiring plaintiffs to post a $1,000 bond. The injunction requires OPM to file reports describing processes put in place since March 6, 2025 to ensure Privacy Act compliance for any new grants of access to systems containing personally identifiable information.

Several related cases challenging similar DOGE activities at other federal agencies were filed in other federal districts, with mixed results on preliminary relief motions. The case remains in preliminary stages with no trial scheduled yet.

The American Bar Association filed this lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Justice, Attorney General Pamela J. Bondi, and Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche on April 23, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia before Judge Christopher R. Cooper. The case was represented by private counsel from Democracy Forward Foundation.

The dispute arose after the ABA publicly criticized the Trump Administration in February and March 2025 for actions it viewed as undermining the judiciary and legal profession, and joined a lawsuit challenging the Administration's freeze on international development grants. In response, Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche issued a memorandum on April 9, 2025, titled "Engagement with the American Bar Association," which prohibited DOJ employees from participating in ABA events on official time and restricted policy employees from engaging with the ABA. The memo explicitly cited the ABA's litigation against the government as justification for these restrictions, stating that DOJ must be "careful stewards of the public fisc" and noting that the ABA was taking positions "contrary to the federal government's policies."

The next day, April 10, 2025, DOJ terminated all of the ABA's Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) grants, totaling $3.2 million, which funded the ABA's Commission on Domestic and Sexual Violence (ABA CDSV). The grants supported training and technical assistance for legal practitioners working with domestic violence, sexual assault, and stalking survivors. DOJ cited only that the grants "no longer effectuate agency priorities" under federal regulations, without providing further explanation. No other OVW grants to different organizations were cancelled.

The ABA brought six claims: First Amendment retaliation, First Amendment viewpoint discrimination, unconstitutional conditions on government grants, Fifth Amendment Equal Protection violations, Fifth Amendment Due Process violations, and Administrative Procedure Act violations. The ABA sought declaratory judgment and injunctive relief, specifically requesting a temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction to prevent enforcement of the grant terminations and require continued funding.

On April 24, 2025, the ABA filed a motion for temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction. The government moved to dismiss on May 2, 2025, arguing primarily on jurisdictional grounds that the claims belonged in the Court of Federal Claims under the Tucker Act rather than federal district court.

Following a hearing on May 12, 2025, Judge Cooper issued a memorandum opinion on May 14, 2025, granting the preliminary injunction on the First Amendment retaliation claim. The court found that the ABA was likely to succeed on the merits of its retaliation claim, noting that the government did not meaningfully contest the merits and that the timing and circumstances strongly suggested retaliation for protected First Amendment activity. The court rejected the government's jurisdictional challenge, finding that the First Amendment retaliation claim had a constitutional rather than contractual source and therefore fell within the district court's jurisdiction rather than the Tucker Act's exclusive domain. The court reserved judgment on the ABA's other claims and granted preliminary relief to prevent DOJ from enforcing the grant terminations based on retaliatory motives.

On March 7, 2025, three transgender inmates in federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) custody filed a class action lawsuit challenging Executive Order 14168, which President Donald Trump issued on January 20, 2025. The plaintiffs—Alishea Kingdom, Solo Nichols, and Jas Kapule—had all been diagnosed with gender dysphoria and were receiving gender-affirming care including hormone therapy and social accommodations like appropriate undergarments and commissary items.

Executive Order 14168, titled "Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government," prohibited the expenditure of federal funds for "any medical procedure, treatment, or drug for the purpose of conforming an inmate's appearance to that of the opposite sex." BOP implemented this directive through two memoranda in February 2025, resulting in the discontinuation or threatened discontinuation of the plaintiffs' hormone therapy and elimination of their access to social accommodations.

The plaintiffs, represented by attorneys from the ACLU Foundation, Transgender Law Center, and Morgan Lewis LLP, filed suit against President Trump, Attorney General Pamela Bondi, and several BOP officials in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. They alleged violations of the Fifth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, the Eighth Amendment's prohibition on cruel and unusual punishment, the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and the Administrative Procedure Act. The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to restore their access to gender-affirming care.

On March 17, 2025, the plaintiffs filed motions for preliminary injunction and class certification. The proposed class included all current and future BOP inmates diagnosed with gender dysphoria who were receiving or would receive gender-affirming health care absent the executive order's prohibition. Judge Royce C. Lamberth conducted a hearing on May 22, 2025.

On June 3, 2025, Judge Lamberth issued a memorandum opinion granting both motions. The court found that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their APA claims, determining that BOP's implementing memoranda were arbitrary and capricious because they provided no reasoned explanation for denying gender-affirming care and failed to adequately consider the agency's sudden policy reversal. The court certified a class of all current and future BOP inmates with gender dysphoria diagnoses and appointed class counsel. The preliminary injunction ordered BOP to restore social accommodations to class members and continue providing hormone therapy to those previously prescribed such treatment.

The court found the plaintiffs faced irreparable harm, noting that gender dysphoria can cause severe symptoms including depression, anxiety, and suicidal ideation without treatment. While some plaintiffs had hormone therapy restored during litigation, the court determined this was done in response to the lawsuit rather than through genuine medical reassessment.

Twenty-four states, led by Indiana and Idaho, filed an amicus brief supporting the defendants, arguing that the controversial treatments were within policymakers' authority to regulate and that prisoners do not have greater rights to such treatments than free citizens.

On August 8, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a renewed motion for preliminary injunction, which Judge Lamberth granted on August 20, 2025, enjoining implementation of the executive order against class members from September 1 through November 30, 2025. The case remains pending, with defendants having filed their answer on June 24, 2025. A separate motion to intervene was filed by Carla Keys on July 14, 2025.
